poem:
**Splat's Reverie**

In the theater of forgettable nights,  
credits roll like tumbleweeds,  
limp horrors morph to graceless jesters,  
comedies dispatch thought's last whisper.  
Sex scenes, stripped bare, no pulse,  
Jim Carrey dons a foreign tongue,  
detective hat perched askew.  
Alone in the dark, I watch myself,  
clapping for the ghosts of plot.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Splat’s entertainment: I watched Rotten Tomatoes’ 40 lowest-rated films to find out which was worst I have seen horrors so limp and lifeless they have turned into comedies. I have seen comedies so dedicated to killing every last one of your brain cells that they have become total horrors. I have seen sex scenes drained of all sex. I have seen Jim Carrey play against type as a hardboiled detective with a light Polish accent.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
